title: Question 97

children: A 25-year-old woman is evaluated for a 4-month history of easy bruising and menorrhagia. She has had recent onset of weekly tension headaches treated with over-the-counter medications but no other problems. At the ages of 19 and 21 years, she had two uneventful vaginal deliveries.
Laboratory studies show a normal complete blood count, prothrombin time, and activated partial thromboplastin time.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

Several over-the-counter medications, such as aspirin, NSAIDs, and herbal supplements, have been implicated in qualitative platelet defects, which often present with increased bleeding or exacerbation of an underlying minor bleeding problem.
In this patient with new-onset easy bruising and menorrhagia, over-the-counter medication use (

) should be carefully assessed before extensive testing begins. Several over-the-counter medications, such as aspirin, NSAIDs, and herbal supplements, have been implicated in qualitative platelet defects, which often present with increased bleeding or exacerbation of an underlying minor bleeding problem. These medications may also interfere with laboratory testing, such as platelet function testing, so it is necessary to elicit an accurate medication history.
Platelet function can be assessed by various laboratory tests. A platelet function analyzer may be used as an initial screening test, replacing the traditional bleeding time (

). The test is run on a citrated blood sample exposed to collagen and either epinephrine or adenosine diphosphate. It is a sensitive test for von Willebrand disease (vWD) and will detect abnormalities caused by antiplatelet medications. Platelet aggregation tests are very sensitive and are affected by various drugs and supplements; therefore, aggregation tests should not precede a review of over-the-counter medications.

) and rotational thromboelastometry are bedside devices that analyze platelet function, coagulation, and clot stability and may be useful as screening tests in patients with unexplained bleeding. However, a careful medication review may reveal the cause of this patient's excess bleeding.

vWD is the most common inherited bleeding disorder. Type 1 vWD, which is the mildest and most common type, usually begins at an early age and presents with mild bleeding symptoms, such as nosebleeds, easy bruising, and menorrhagia. Prothrombin time may be elevated or normal. It is not uncommon for children with mild symptoms not to be diagnosed with vWD. Therefore, it is reasonable to screen for vWD (

) in adult patients with suggestive symptoms but only after a review of over-the-counter medicationâ€“related qualitative platelet disorders. This patient's two previous uneventful vaginal deliveries argue against vWD.

objective.__html: Diagnose qualitative platelet disorder related to medication use.
